moves.7... c6 8. O-O Nbd7 9. Qc2 Re8 10. e4: Preferable was a3, because white can then continue with b4, a4 and b5, weakening black's Queenside. Here, white concedes a small portion of his/her central advantage by losing a key centre pawn.
moves.13... b6 14. Rfd1 Bb7 15. c5: I'm not quite sure what white wanted to accomplish with this move. Perhaps he/she feared the c5 push, which would only lose to dXc5. Now, the square d5 makes a nice nest for black's knight on f6.
moves.15... Nd5 16. Ne5 Qf6: Not quite sure why I played this move. I may have wanted to play Rook d8 as a follow up. In hindsight, this is a slow plan. I don't think there was anything better though.
moves.17. Nc4 Ba6: A mistake. I tried to get tempo and greater scope for my bishop, but leave d6 wide open for white's knight to settle. This secures a great advantage for white.
moves.18. Nd6 Red8 19. a3: Better is Rc1, developing a major piece onto a half open C file. White also has the crushing Ne4, which actually wins a pawn after Qe7, cxb6, axb6, Qxc6.
moves.19... Rab8: Trying to get counter play which actually works towards the end of the game. Right now, there's not a whole lot I can do.
moves.20. b4 Bb7: Will white take the bishop? Probably not, but I was trying to remove the Knight at all costs.
moves.21. Rd3 a5: I create an open b file.
moves.22. bxa5 bxc5 23. Qxc5 Ba6 24. Rf3: White has an extra pawn and a great position. All is well...
moves.24... Qg6 25. Nxf7: This completely loses. Being trapped in a false sense of security, white thinks, "I'm up one pawn, lets grab another!" Black now gains an unstoppable attack.
moves.26. Bf1: White can't take the rook on account of checkmate.
moves.26... Bxf1: If black takes the rook, white takes the rook with the Knight and has a checkmate of his/her own.
moves.27. Nh6+: A desperate fling. Hoping for Qxh6 and then Rxb1
moves.27... gxh6: This should be an insurmountable deficit. White resigns.
